coredata.dc:title: Ammonium ion coordination in concentrated aqueous ammonium chloride
coredata.dc:creator: Hewish, N.A.
Neilson, G.W.
coredata.dc:description:
Abstract
Results of a neutron-diffraction study on 5.0 molal ammonium chloride in heavy water were used to determine the ND+ 4 water conformation. There are between 10 and 11 water molecules coordinated to the ammonium ion in the range 2.60–4.35 Å. The coordination is not well defined and although in broad agreement with a molecular dynamics study, there are significant differences.

Introduction Several years ago an attempt was made to deter- mine the coordination of water around chloride and ammonium ions m aqueous NI^Cl solutions [1]. It was concluded that a model in which Cl~ was coor- dinated to 6 water molecules and NH^ to 4 water molecules was consistent with the X-ray diffraction results. Two further attempts have been made in recent years [2,3] but with special emphasis on the coordi- nation of the ammonium ion. One group [2] points out that m X-ray studies it wfll not be easy to find a unique model for the ammonium ion consistent with the view originally proposed by Narten [ 1 ] on the basis of the inability of X-rays to distinguish between two atomic species with almost the same number of electrons. Such a comment may be raised generally when the scattering strength of ions m solution is less than or close to that for water molecules. The ammonium ion possesses the same number of electrons as the water molecule, and furthermore, where the hydration is short lived ( <10~12 s, in which case we prefer the term "coordination") it is unlikely that a single diffraction measurement wfll be able to identify the ion water structure unambiguously. This follows from the resultant broadening of any peaks in the real-space transform of the diffraction data, taken together with the large number of those peaks to be expected in a total diffraction experiment. It is there- fore debatable whether total diffraction patterns de- rived from X-ray or neutron experiments can provide a unique answer to the important questions concern- ing iomc hydration in a weakly coordinating system. Nevertheless, a diffraction study combined with the powerful technique of molecular dynamics can be used to rule out certain structures [3]. In the present investigation we have undertaken a neutron-diffraction study on a concentrated ammo- nium chloride heavy water solution. The first-order difference method [4] was applied using two nitrogen isotopes, and in this way structural infonnatioa could be derived from the viewpoint of the ammonium ion. The results were used to resolve the disagreement between the two X-ray diffraction studies, and to de- termine whether there is indeed a well-defined hydra- tion structure around ND^. Since ND^ is monovalent, the structural results are useful in a comparison with other monovalent ions notably the alkalis of which Li4' is the first in the series. An extensive study has al- ready been carried out on this ion in concentrated UCI'D^O solutions [5]. 2. We have not attempted any further analysis of G^(r) and limit our discussion to the above results. If we assume a fundamental spherical symmetry for the ND^ ion, then it is clear that its surrounding water molecules are not in a well-defined conforma- tion, in contrast to Li"*" water coordination studies [5] The molecular dynamics results of Szasz and Heinzinger [8j (shown for comparison in fig. 2), in which they used the ST2 potential to describe the water molecules, and a Lennard-Jones sphere with ap- propriate point charges to describe the NH$ ion, show clearly that for such potentials the ammonium ion will be hydrated with 10 water molecules in the first shell. The neutron result is in broad agreement with the simulation, and indeed a calculation of the number of water molecules coordinated to ND^ gives a value of 10 11. There is however a large discrepancy arising from the overall shape of the G^(r). The MD result is much sharper than that derived from experiment, and would appear to overestimate either theAydrating strength of the ND^ ion, or the spherical nature of its effective potential. Similar observations have been made on Cl hydra- tion, where the simulation gives a much more struc- tured distribution function than is determined experi- mentally [9]. Clearly, the type of ion water potential chosen is crucial and it will be interesting to discover what result would be obtained from a non-central po- tential. We are unable to comment directly on the X-ray results insofar as they concern the NH^ water contri- bution to the total intensity pattern. It must be noted (and here we agree with Musmu et al. [2]) that where lighter elements or those with comparable scattering strengths to water are present in aqueous solution, then the extraction of a unique correlation between such elements and water molecules is extremely diffi- cult. However, when used in conjunction with com- puter simulation a good first-order guide can be ob- tained for the ion water conformation.
